verses.text: In the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah, Hoshea son of Elah became king of Israel in Samaria, and he reigned nine years.
verses.comment: Strictly follows the original naming and details of the kings’ reigns.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, yet not like the kings of Israel who were before him.
verses.comment: Preserves the comparison to prior kings’ wickedness.

verses.text: Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against him. Hoshea became his servant and paid him tribute.
verses.comment: Retains the relationship between Hoshea and his Assyrian overlord.

verses.text: But the king of Assyria found conspiracy in Hoshea, for he had sent messengers to So king of Egypt and no longer paid tribute to the king of Assyria, as he had done each year. Therefore the king of Assyria shut him up and imprisoned him in prison.
verses.comment: ‘Shut him up’ matches the Hebrew; ‘prison’ instead of ‘house of confinement’ for clarity.

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria invaded the whole land, and he came up to Samaria and besieged it for three years.
verses.comment: Complete rendering of the Assyrian siege.

verses.text: In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria captured Samaria and carried Israel away to Assyria. He settled them in Halah, on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
verses.comment: Stays literal—specifies exile locations as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: Now this happened because the people of Israel had sinned against the LORD their God, who had brought them up out of the land of Egypt from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and had feared other gods.
verses.comment: Summarizes the theological reason for exile.

verses.text: They walked in the statutes of the nations whom the LORD had driven out before the people of Israel, and in the statutes introduced by the kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Retains reference to borrowed pagan customs.

verses.text: The people of Israel secretly did things against the LORD their God that were not right. They built for themselves high places in all their towns, from the watchtower to the fortified city.
verses.comment: ‘From the watchtower to the fortified city’ reflects every settlement.

verses.text: They set up for themselves sacred pillars and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
verses.comment: ‘Asherah poles’—transliterated for clarity of the idol's identity.

verses.text: There they burned incense on all the high places, just as the nations did whom the LORD carried away before them. They did evil things provoking the LORD to anger.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; ‘provoking the LORD to anger’ is idiomatic but literal.

verses.text: They served idols, of which the LORD had said to them, 'You shall not do this thing.'
verses.comment: Preserves the explicit command.

verses.text: Yet the LORD warned Israel and Judah by every prophet and every seer, saying, 'Turn from your evil ways and keep My commandments and My statutes, according to all the law that I commanded your fathers, and that I sent to you by My servants the prophets.'
verses.comment: Accurate quotation of God's warning message.

verses.text: But they would not listen. Instead they were stubborn, as their fathers had been, who did not believe in the LORD their God.
verses.comment: ‘Stubborn’ preserves the sense of ‘stiff-necked’.

verses.text: They rejected His statutes and His covenant that He made with their fathers, and the warnings that He gave them. They went after empty idols and became empty, and they followed the nations that were around them, concerning whom the LORD had commanded them not to do as they did.
verses.comment: ‘Went after empty idols and became empty’ keeps Hebrew wordplay—‘hebel’.

verses.text: They abandoned all the commandments of the LORD their God and made for themselves molten images, two calves, and they made an Asherah, and worshiped all the host of heaven and served Baal.
verses.comment: Explicitly lists the specific sins as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: They made their sons and daughters pass through the fire, practiced divination and sorcery, and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the LORD, provoking Him to anger.
verses.comment: 'Pass through the fire' refers to child sacrifice—a literal rendering.

verses.text: Therefore the LORD was very angry with Israel and removed them from His sight. There was none left but the tribe of Judah only.
verses.comment: Literal phraseology—‘removed them from His sight’.

verses.text: Even Judah did not keep the commandments of the LORD their God, but walked in the customs that Israel had introduced.
verses.comment: Jewish kingdom’s complicity included.

verses.text: So the LORD rejected all the descendants of Israel and afflicted them and gave them into the hand of plunderers, until He had cast them out of His sight.
verses.comment: ‘All descendants of Israel’ matches the Hebrew ‘seed of Israel’.

verses.text: When He tore Israel from the house of David, they made Jeroboam son of Nebat king. Jeroboam drove Israel away from following the LORD and caused them to commit a great sin.
verses.comment: ‘Tore Israel’ recalls the divided monarchy.

verses.text: The people of Israel walked in all the sins that Jeroboam committed; they did not depart from them.
verses.comment: Plain, matching chronic summary statements elsewhere.

verses.text: Until the LORD removed Israel out of His sight, as He had spoken by all His servants the prophets. So Israel was carried away from their own land to Assyria to this day.
verses.comment: 'To this day'—retains the original time reference.

verses.text: The king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim, and settled them in the cities of Samaria in place of the people of Israel. They took possession of Samaria and lived in its cities.
verses.comment: Names of foreign cities transliterated.

verses.text: At the beginning of their dwelling there, they did not fear the LORD. So the LORD sent lions among them, which killed some of them.
verses.comment: ‘Sent lions’ is meant as a sign of judgment.

verses.text: So they spoke to the king of Assyria and said, 'The nations you have carried away and settled in the cities of Samaria do not know the customs of the God of the land. Therefore He has sent lions among them, and behold, they are killing them because they do not know the customs of the God of the land.'
verses.comment: Rendering ‘customs’ for ‘judgment’ (mishpat) to match pagan understanding.

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria commanded, 'Send there one of the priests whom you carried away from there; let him go and live there and teach them the customs of the God of the land.'
verses.comment: Priest sent to reintroduce Israelite worship practices.

verses.text: So one of the priests whom they had carried away from Samaria came and lived in Bethel and taught them how they should fear the LORD.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of ‘fear the LORD’.

verses.text: But every nation still made gods of their own and put them in the shrines of the high places that the Samaritans had made, every nation in the cities where they lived.
verses.comment: ‘Samaritans’ could also read ‘people of Samaria’.

verses.text: The men of Babylon made Succoth-benoth, the men of Cuth made Nergal, the men of Hamath made Ashima,
verses.comment: Pagan god names transliterated per tradition.

verses.text: the Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak, and the Sepharvites burned their children in the fire to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sepharvaim.
verses.comment: Clarifies ‘burned their children’ refers to child sacrifice.

verses.text: So they also feared the LORD and appointed from among themselves all sorts of people as priests for the high places, who sacrificed for them in the shrines of the high places.
verses.comment: ‘All sorts of people’ for ‘from every class’ (not Levites).

verses.text: They feared the LORD but also served their own gods, after the custom of the nations from among whom they had been carried away.
verses.comment: Depicts their syncretism.

verses.text: To this day they do according to the earlier customs. They do not fear the LORD, and they do not follow the statutes, the ordinances, the law, or the commandments that the LORD commanded the children of Jacob, whom He named Israel.
verses.comment: Original’s fourfold law references kept in modern diction.

verses.text: The LORD had made a covenant with them and had commanded them, 'You shall not fear other gods or bow yourselves to them or serve them or sacrifice to them.'
verses.comment: Direct quote of God’s command.

verses.text: But you shall fear the LORD, who brought you out of the land of Egypt with great power and an outstretched arm. You shall bow yourselves to Him, and to Him you shall sacrifice.
verses.comment: ‘With great power and outstretched arm’ retains ancient idiom.

verses.text: The statutes and the ordinances and the law and the commandment that He wrote for you, you shall always be careful to do. You shall not fear other gods.
verses.comment: Fourfold reference matches verse 34, repeats for emphasis.

verses.text: And the covenant that I have made with you, you shall not forget. And you shall not fear other gods.
verses.comment: Repeats command for emphasis as in Hebrew.

verses.text: But you shall fear the LORD your God, and He will deliver you out of the hand of all your enemies.
verses.comment: God’s promise of deliverance for exclusive worship.

verses.text: But they would not listen. Instead they did according to their former customs.
verses.comment: ‘Former customs’ emphasizes their persistence in syncretism.

verses.text: So these nations feared the LORD and also served their carved images. Their children and their children's children continue to do as their fathers did, to this day.
verses.comment: Concludes with generational persistence of syncretism.
